root: ^The watch on your wrist hums unobtrusively.
^Squinting your eyes, you see the familiar notification.
^Groaning, you pull yourself up, nudging your partner. They wake - their wrist also vibrating.

^<i>Cluck cluck! Egg farms considering replacing hen caretakers with more efficient egg-collecting machines. These tiny robots hustle behind their bird counterpart, scooping up eggs as quickly as they are laid.

s: ^Ignore the notification and go back to sleep.

c-0: ^The image of a little tin man shoving eggs into cartons as big as himself makes you chuckle.
c-1: ^You and your partner eat two eggs every morning and have never struggled to find them in the grocery store. No need to crack a system that isn't broken.
c-2: ^Not expressing an opinion is an opinion. Whether that opinion is: you truly have no preference, or, in this case, you care more about your sleep, only you will know.
g-0: ^Your partner groggily taps her screen then immediately starts snoring again. The soft glow from your watches gently fades.

c-3: ^These interruptions in the night are commonplace, and while irritating, an important part of democracy and a functioning government.
^Your partner prides herself on making tiny sacrifices for the greater good, which means getting used to waking up in the middle of the night.
^The morning comes without warning while you're philosophizing. You head into the kitchen to start on your breakfast while your partner snoozes.
c-4: ^Your partner prides herself on making tiny sacrifices for the greater good. Insomnia is a small price to pay for being a good partner and a good citizen.
^You watch the curtains gradually light up as the sun rises. You head into the kitchen to start on your breakfast while your partner snoozes.
c-5: ^The fridge's florescent light helps wake you up. Inspired by your recent vote, you pull out some eggs and bread for toast.

^Despite your partner being an unwavering advocate of democratic participation at any hour, she is suprisingly flightly with their food preferences. You'll wait until she's up to figure out her breakfast.

s: ^Hold the coffee grinder super close to the bedroom door.

c-6: ^You hear a thump and then a swear as she finally gets up and moving.
c-7: ^You hear the thump of a pillow being thrown against the door and then a groan.

g-2: ^The acrid scent of freshly ground beans floats through the air as your partner groggily plods in and collapses into the kitchen stool.
^They squint menacingly at the sunlight shining through the sink window.

s: ^Slide over a mug of coffee and the creamer.

c-8: ^You've learned over the years that the graphic tee adage of: "Don't talk to me until I've had my coffee" really applies to your partner.
^As she sips, her forehead crinkles smooth out and she stops internally cursing the open window.
c-9: ^"Dreamt about eggs and tiny robot men."
^"Couldn't really tell. I think they were more worried about getting trampled underfoot."
c-10: ^"It'll be busy, but probably not too bad compared to your work. At least I get to be sheltered in the elements rather than on-site at some dusty mausoleum."
^"Hey now, that's a precious heritage of our past, and more importantly, what I spent eight years in school for."

s: ^"So, what'd you vote for? Egg automation or no egg automation?"

EggVote: ^The lines around your partner's mouth crinkle downward. While highly recommended against (but not enforced), it is considered incredibly impolite to ask someone directly how they voted or if they chose to vote.
^"Care about the right for your fellow man to harvest eggs?"
^Her attempt at a joke comes off abrasive.

c-0: ^"It's not though. In the grand scheme of things, it's a very unimportant topic."
^Breakfast is an awkward affair, the broken yolks of your sunny-side up eggs a painfully apt metaphor for your morning.
c-1: ^It's a bad excuse, but they seem somewhat appeased, waving a lazy hand to dismiss the blunder.
^They, somewhat pointedly, grab a box of about-to-be-stale cereal. You could point out that it'll probably be dry and powdery, but decide against it. The dry-wet crunching grates on your ears.
c-2: ^"Well, next time, can you wait until we're at least done with breakfast?
^Breakfast is an awkward affair, the broken yolks of your sunny-side up eggs a painfully apt metaphor for your morning.

EggVoteSkirt:
^
The lines around your partner's mouth wrinkle slightly.
^"Are you curious about how I voted? Because then you can just ask."

s: ^"No, no, sorry, just making a joke. Came out poorly."

c-0: ^While highly recommended against (but not enforced), it is considered incredibly impolite to ask someone directly how they voted or if they chose to vote.
^"I'm just teasing. Don't look so worried on a Monday. Make me some of the last eggs before our robot overlords take over."
^You actually are using the last eggs in the fridge. You'll have to grab some on the way home.
c-1: ^While highly recommended against (but not enforced), it is considered incredibly impolite to ask someone directly how they voted or if they chose to vote.
^Her appreciation of your bluntness seems to be battling her irritation at being asked.
^"I voted against it. Why fix what's not broken?"
^Both of you speed through breakfast to make the train.

s: ^Hustle to catch your morning train in silence.
^Wish your partner a good day at work before you leave.

c-0: ^Your partner gives you an absentminded wave on her way out, not noticing your silence.
c-1: ^She reminds you to take your rain jacket in case you go on-site.
g-0: ^The rumble of the metro drowns out the buzz on your wrist. Only the unnatural lull in conversation has you looking down out of habit.
^You find it eerie, but your partner likes to call these: "moments of silent democracy".

^Farms in the Midwest are experiencing severe drought as natural reservoirs dry up. Implement a nation wide campaign of cloud seeding. Cloud seeding by depositing silver iodide into the sky encourages water condensation and rainfall.

c-2: ^I'm singing in the rain! You're singing in the rain! We're all singing in the rain!
c-3: ^There has got to be other solutions before dumping chemicals into the sky.

g-1: ^People stream around you on the train. Something about the fluidity of public transport is so

c-5: ^ soulless. All those bodies, fluttering around in steel cages.
c-6: ^ efficient. We live in a world where you can transport yourself anywhere, anytime (within regulated hours and lanes).
c-7: ^ peaceful. There is a single-minded focus on the task of physical movement.

g-2: ^The rain starts beating a tempo on the metal roof.

b: ^ Your partner normally reminds you of the weather. Looks like you're cooling your head one way or another.
^ At least you have your rain jacket.

g-2: ^One more vote interrupts your contemplation before you leave the train.

^Strategic cloud seeding could improve military effectiveness by disrupting foreign encampment, allowing for traversal or blockades, or creating natural water resources to reduce resources required in naturally arid environments.

b: ^ Wow, we're really all singing in the rain.
^ Except if it can help our troops.
^ You'd think they would just apply my previous opinion.
^ Doing it for our farms is fine, doing it outside of our grounds is not.
^ Let it never be said that you're inconsistent.

g-4: ^Couldn't they have made this into one vote? Manipulate the weather or don't.
^Sloshing your way into work, you catch the elevator heading to artists' floor.
^On the way up, you enter into an animated conversation with Jerry, one of the marketing managers, on the new cafe offerings.
^Zenoxia has imposed tarrifs on rare earth metals. This will drastically increase the cost of computer chips for us in the near future.
^Raise export costs on their primary food source.
g-5: ^"Note to self: we've got to upgrade our PCs as soon as possible," Jerry mumbles as he finishes tapping.
^Your country likes to call it the "perfect form of anonymous democracy", but sometimes, it's pretty easy to tell how people voted.

s: ^Let your day at work slip by.

WorkSlack:
^

There's a 17th century vase you've been trying to replicate in virtual reality. Tugging on your goggles, you waste your hours playing around with natural light shadows rather than making any progress.
^You need to wrap this up by end of week. There's a new project you've been volunteered for: on replicating modern day homeowner houses in virtual reality on a one to one basis.

s: ^Take a break to check the vote.

WorkGrind:
^

There's a 17th century vase you've been trying to replicate in virtual reality. Tugging on your goggles, you sit and start tracing the individual cracks on your previous 3D model.
^You need to wrap this up by end of week. There's a new project you've been volunteered for: on replicating modern day homeowner houses in virtual reality on a one to one basis.

s: ^Take a break to check the vote.

WorkTime: ^You dial in and start etching the dust motes on the vase. Your company's virtual mausoleum replication project has a series of these perfect one-to-one models, and you'd like to leave your coworkers with as little slack as possible when you switch to the new project.
^Work passes relatively quickly, and you're headed home before you know it.
WarVote: ^Conflicts have risen to an extreme tension point with Zenoxia. Both nation's leaders have announced that war is unavoidable.

s: ^not a part of your daily lives.

WarOpinionDaily: ^War is the realm of politicians and soldiers, neither of which apply to you. It's awful, to be sure, but you're not really sure what you're expected to do about it.
WarOpinionTerrifying: ^You have never experienced a country at war.
^To say you feel dread in the pit of your stomach would be wrong.
^You feel, this weird sensation where you think you should be scared, but there's nothing in your immediate area to be scared of.
^It's as if you're split in two: Your brain is scared and your body hasn't caught up yet, or the other way around.
WarOpinionUnforgiveable: ^You, for the first time, reject the vote. You've disagreed with votes, sure.
^You've railed against certain decisions. But, most fade with time and life goes on.
^This vote though, you reject the premise of. You reject the system that allowed you, the collective, to vote in this way.
WarOpinionInevitable: ^Countries have conflicts, and countries go to war over those conflicts. You're unlucky enough to be living during one of those times, but there's nothing you can do about it.

c-0: ^You're leaning on the sink, doing the dishes in a daze when the front door bangs open.
^Your partner shakes their head like a dog shaking off water.

b:
^ You're still a bit too miffed about the morning to notice their hands are shaking.

"What is up with you? Is this some weird payback about eggs?"

Your partner strides over, seeming to visibly restrain herself from clinging to your shoulders.

c-0: ^Her words come out like a clipped metronome.

b: ^ You're not going to be ashamed of your vote.
^ Why did you say that? You didn't vote for the war.
^ Why did you say that? Maybe she'll be less furious than if she found out you ignored the vote all together."

s: ^not a part of our daily lives."

b: ^ You're lying? She'll never forgive you if she finds out.
^ You meet her eyes squarely.
^ You're lying? She'll never forgive you if she finds out.

s: ^not a part of our daily lives."

b: ^ Why did you say that? Do you think this is better than her finding out you ignored the vote?
^ You're lying? She'll never forgive you if she finds out.
^ You won't compromise the integrity of your choice.

s: ^not a part of our daily lives."
^Head home, satisifed with a well-done day of work.

c-0: ^The front door bangs open and your partner rushes in.
^Your partner shakes their head like a dog shaking off water.

b:
^ You're still a bit too miffed about the morning to notice their hands are shaking.

"What is up with you? Is this some weird payback about eggs?"

Your partner strides over, seeming to visibly restrain themselves from clinging to your shoulders.

"You didn't vote? You missed it?"

s: ^not a part of your daily lives.

WarOpinionDailyMissed: ^War is the realm of politicians and soldiers, neither of which apply to you. It's awful, to be sure, but you're not really sure what you're expected to do about it.
WarOpinionTerrifyingMissed: ^You have never experienced a country at war.
^To say you feel dread in the pit of your stomach would be wrong.
^You feel, this weird sensation where you think you should be scared, but there's nothing in your immediate area to be scared of.
^It's as if you're split in two: Your brain is scared and your body hasn't caught up yet, or the other way around.
WarOpinionUnforgiveableMissed: ^You, for the first time, reject the vote. You've disagreed with votes, sure.
^You've railed against certain decisions. But, most fade with time and life goes on.
^This vote though, you reject the premise of. You reject the system that allowed you, the collective, to vote in this way.
WarOpinionInevitableMissed: ^Countries have conflicts, and countries go to war over those conflicts. You're unlucky enough to be living during one of those times, but there's nothing you can do about it.
MissedConversation:
^

You take an involuntary step back. You've never seen that expression on their face before.
^"No, I voted to not be at war. You, apparently, didn't vote at all."
^"I had work. It's our right to ignore a vote."

s: ^"War is not a part of our daily lives."

b:
^

She holds up a hand. "I don't want to hear it. I'm going to leave before either of us says anything we'll regret. I'll come back before tomorrow."
Without waiting, she strides back out into the downpour.

^You've never lied about your opinion to placate her and you're not going to start now.

"We'll be fine. It won't touch us."

"Oh, so it's all fine because we're not in the military?"

You reach out but she breaks away and slams out the door.

^"We'll be fine. It won't touch us."

"Oh, so it's all fine because we're not in the military?"

You reach out but she breaks away and slams out the door.

You thought she would also be frightened, so you tried to comfort her. But she seems more enraged than frightened.

^"We'll be fine. It won't touch us."

"Oh, so it's all fine because we're not in the military?"

You reach out but she breaks away and slams out the door.

You understand her rage, but you don't understand why she's taking it out on you. She's not the only one angry at the world right now.

^"We'll be fine. It won't touch us."

"Oh, so it's all fine because we're not in the military?"

You reach out but she breaks away and slams out the door.

You don't understand why she has to take her rage at the world out on you right now.

^You reach out to comfort her. "I understand you're scared. I'm scared too, but we'll be okay."

She might feel better if you try to empathize, but she brushes you off. "I'm not scared, I'm furious. What sort of-"

She cuts herself off, then turns and walks out the door.

^ Her expression softens.

"Come here, I shouldn't have taken it out on you, I'm sorry."

You hold each other for a brief moment before she lets go.

"Sorry, I need to head out. I have to go check on some people."

Before you can stop her, she's out the door into the downpour.

^She grabs your hand.

"We have to fix this."

She hesistates, then shakes her head.

"I'll be back. I need to go check on some friends."

^ Her expression softens.

"Come here, I shouldn't have taken it out on you, I'm sorry."

You hold each other for a brief moment before she lets go.

"Sorry, I need to head out. I have to go check on some people."

Before you can stop her, she's out the door into the downpour.

^ She seems furious. Perhaps if you match her anger, it will help calm her down.

"But, what can we do about this?"

She seems to measure you in a glance, and finds you lacking.

"I'll be back."

She strides out of the still swinging door without a word.

^ She grabs your hand.

"We have to fix this."

She hesistates, then shakes her head.

"I'll be back. I need to go check on some friends."

^ She grabs your hand.

"We'll fix this."

She hesistates, as if about to say more, then shakes her head.

"I'll be back. I need to go check on some friends."

^ Sometimes, the inevitable is unforgiveable, but you're not sure what you can really do about it.

You're broken out of your thoughts by your partner grabbing your hand."We have to fix this."

She hesistates, then shakes her head.

"I'll be back. I need to go check on some friends."

^

She holds up a hand. "I don't want to hear it. I'm going to leave before either of us says anything we'll regret. I'll come back before tomorrow."
Without waiting, she strides back out into the downpour.

^ You understand she's scared, but you try to talk her down. The war won't touch her, and there's nothing she could have done to stop it.

"Inevitable?"

Her voice cracks on the word.

"How can you just sit there and accept it?"

She spins on her heel and sprints back out the still swinging door.

^ This is no time to show your fear; you'll have to weather this storm together.

"Inevitable?"

Her voice cracks on the word.

"How can you just sit there and accept it?"

She spins on her heel and sprints back out the still swinging door.

^ "Inevitable?"

Her voice cracks on the word.

"How can you just sit there and accept it?"

You didn't mean it that way. Before you can explain, she spins on her heel and sprints back out the still swinging door.

^ "Inevitable?"

Her voice cracks on the word.

"How can you just sit there and accept it?"

She spins on her heel and sprints back out the still swinging door.

NextDay:
^

You both spend the next few weeks in a fog. The mundanity of your new project, making perfect VR replicas of random homeowners' residences soothes you, in a way. The normalcy of modern living.
^Her side of the bed is often cold, but she's been coming and leaving at odd hours. You decide to just give her some space.
DrivetoParents: ^You load the car with obligatory homecoming gifts while your partner sits on the doorstep watching ants hustle indoors for the winter. There’s a taste of the big city for your mother, donuts filled with jelly and cream (disgustingly slimy things, you never had a taste for them), and for your father, a case of fancy IPAs (which he won’t actually drink, but they give him an excuse to talk about how the local brewery does it right).
^You slam the trunk shut, then stare at your partner, who is still contemplating an ant slipping on its version of a driveway.

s: ^"Want to talk to me at all?"
^"It's not my fault I missed the vote."
^"Are you still blaming me for my vote? The one you asked me to tell you?"

DrivetoParentsHouseFriendly: ^They look over, and then give a half-smile.
^“Thanks. I’m not really up to talking. Still a bit in shock, I guess.”
^“No problem, hey, you can even put on your playlist if you want. I won’t complain about whichever new underground artist you’re discovering.”

s: ^“Ok, I reserve the right to complain past the one hour mark.”
^“No complaints, I swear, but my driving will be tied to how good they are.”
^“Uhh, maybe we switch at the half-way point?”

g-0: ^“No takebacks. Time to introduce you to folk mixed with sea-faring tunes.”
^Groaning, you get behind the wheel as they gleefully plug in the aux.

DrivetoParentsUnfriendly: ^They blow a piece of their hair out of their face, in a seemingly frustrated manner.
^“I’m just a little down, okay? Not everyday your country literally declares war.”
^Their finger traces a little line in the snow for their ant friend to follow.

c-1: ^“Thanks. I think I just need some quiet, especially before we see your parents.”

QuietDrivetoParents: ^The familiar drive whips by as you both stare out your respective windows, with a quiet pitstop for coffee and an unspoken agreement to swap seats.
DrivetoParentsArgument: ^Their back stiffens as their eyes remained fixedly on the frantic scurrying of the ants.
^Their rote quote of the official campaign, memorized by every grade schooler when they first attended mandatory civic training, is a slap in the face.

s: ^Just because they’re hurting doesn’t make it fair to hurt you.

BackoffArgument: ^“Sorry, I’ll drop it. You want to take some time? I can go visit my folks by myself.”
^They run their fingers through the snow, then resolutely stand up.
^“No, we should go. Moping won’t change anything.”

s: ^“I can drive. Why don’t you get some rest in the car?”
^Alright, if we’re going to go, let’s go.

b: ^ "Not voting is a vote."
^ "Differences in voting are a sign of a healthy, functioning democracy."

ContinueArgument: ^Your partner doesn't even raise their eyes.
MeetingParentsTired: ^Your partner naps, or at least pretends to, for the car ride. You play your music quietly to not wake them, although you’re not sure if it’s out of kindness or because you also want to be alone for a bit.
MeetingParentsNoDrive: ^You could press the point, but something in their lack of eye contact tells you to not push it.
^The two hour car ride continues in silence.
MeetingParentsHappy: ^The car is freezing. Your partner hasn’t spoken, which is uncommon for them, but has been repeatedly rolling the window up and down to the beat while head bopping.
HappyMusic: ^You and your partner bop the whole way on the drive (in a safe, and traffic-law abiding manner).
AnnoyingMusic: ^“Ah, ah,” your partner waves their finger at you, “no complaints about my music means no complaints about the enjoyment of my music.”

c-0: ^ “Seriously, you’re going to damage something, and it’s below zero outside.”
c-1: ^ “Alright, at least sacrifice your scarf to me in the name of your artistic appreciation.”

ArgueMusic: ^The window rolls up and they turn their face away.
^Nice going, they had just gotten out of their funk.
^You don’t bother asking if they want to switch and take a turn driving when you pull over at a mid-way rest stop.

s: ^Shut off the music for the rest of the drive.

MeetingParents: ^Your car rumbles up to your parent’s place – which they’ve been paying a mortgage on for as long as you can remember. This is the house where you hassled birds and made dandelion soup in the fenced off backyard, where the only update to your childhood bedroom is a little more clutter stored and a fresh set of linens every time you visit.
^Your mother and father are waiting patiently on the driveway. Your mother is holding another massive scarf that she’s dug out from her department store couponing.
ParentResponseWait: ^Your partner adores your parents - they always cheer them up.
^“It wasn’t too bad! The roads were icy, but everyone was slipping a bit, so no one was too reckless.”

g-0: ^“Well, don’t just stand there, come in,” your mother bustles about as she lays the scarf around your partner’s neck.
^“Sorry,” your father shrugs, “I tried telling her that – even if you two are cold – it’s only a few feet from the car door to the front door.”
^Your mother is already brushing snow off her shoes as she shouts behind her.
^“A cold doesn’t care if you’re cold for a few seconds or for a few hours.”

c-2: ^"Don't fret, there was a holiday sale. We have more winter clothes inside."
c-3: ^He casts a look back at you for a second, but follows his wife in the door.

g-1: ^As you cross the threshold, everyone's watches buzz.

ParentResponseCheerful: ^"Hi, mom! Hi, dad! The drive was exactly the same as it always is."
^Your partner nods in agreement as they're clomping up to the driveway.

s: ^Take the scarf from your mother for yourself.

c-0: ^You wrap the scarf around your neck, shivering in mock-cold.
^"Thanks mom, this will really help me make it from the car door to the drive way."
c-1: ^You wrap the scarf around your partner, who rolls their eyes at you.
^"Thanks, this will really help me make it from the car door to the drive way."
^Your mother is already brushing snow off her shoes as she shouts behind her.
^“A cold doesn’t care if you’re cold for a few seconds or for a few hours.”
g-0: ^As you cross the threshold, everyone's watches buzz.

VRLookFirst: ^Your partner is, at least it feels like, deliberately not looking at you.
VRVote: ^Realistic VR questioning used to elicit more honest responses. By placing informants within  a replica of their home in virtual reality, more accurate information critical to national security can be obtained.
VRVoteApprove: ^It's not explicitly stated, but you know this is what you're work will be used for.
^If your partner ever finds out, you don't think they'll ever forgive you.
VRVoteDeny: ^Your gut drops as you realize what that new project at work has been about.
^There's a perfectly reasonable explanation for how your 'standard house modeling' could be completely unrelated to this initiative.
VRVoteIgnore: ^All you want is for this foreign war to stop impacting your life. You let your wrist drop to your side, deliberately not looking at your partner.
ParentIgnore: ^Your parents don't miss a step as the vote comes and goes, barely glancing at their wrist.
^They've always been of the attitude that you can't change the world.
^Conversely, they're incredibly involved in their community government and initiatives.
^This is something you've explained to your partner multiple times, to limited success.

s: ^Wait for your partner's reaction, be what it is.

ChangeConversation: ^"So, mom -" you start, but your partner is pretty wise to your antics.
LetItHappen: ^"Look," your partner starts hesitantly, "I know it's not polite to remark on."
^You see your mother's back stiffen, her hand pausing on the wooden railing. She knows what's coming, but everyone's too polite to point out impoliteness.
^"But, there are crazy, scary things happening in the world. Maybe, it's time to put your voice to it."

s: ^"Mom, dad, this is really important to my partner. It would mean a lot if you guys made an effort, at least while we're here."

NoPartnerBackUp: ^They hold up their hands in defense.
^"I know, of course, it's their decision." They turn their palms up pleadingly. "But, you're not making decisions, you're letting them be made for you."
^Your father puts a comforting hand on your partner's shoulder.
^"Let's save the politics for at least after dinner, alright? It's the holidays."

s: ^Shoot your partner the 'please drop it' look.

PleaseStopTalking: ^You flick your eyes towards your mother's tense back and then shake your head.
^Your partner sighs, then extends an awkward olive branch.
^"Sorry, Mary, you know how it is. I can't help myself."
^Your mother shakes off the offense as she rounds the corner into the kitchen.
^"No worries dear, the world is a scary place. We all cope with it in our own way."
StopTalking: ^You step up to your mother and take her shoulder, guiding her to the kitchen.
^You stop to give your partner a glare before engaging her in a vivid conversation about what's for dinner.
^You love your partner. But, sometimes, your values on what is appropriate discussion in the house and among family, are different.

s: ^"So, did you let dad use his smoker this year?"
^"We brought you two a little something from the city."

BackupPartner: ^"Can't we at least have dinner before we start talking about politics?"
^You were not raised in a family that discussed the vote, or any vote at all really.
^You hate that this is happening in your childhood home, the family photos on the wall seeming to judge your choice of partner.
Youshouldvote: ^You take your partner's hand. They don't look at you, but you feel them squeeze your hand.
^Your parents exchange a look at your united front.
^"Look, we're not here to argue. Just... just think about it alright?"
^Your partner is the one compromising now.
^"Didn't want to start off on the wrong foot. We'll go wash up, alright?"

s: ^Take some time alone to cool off first.

Dinner: ^You hear the splashing of your partner washing their face.
^When everyone eventually emerges around the dinner table, the atmosphere has smoothed out.

^Aunt Joey, your side, has a new baby. Suzie, your classmate, got married. Work is going well. (You try to steer the conversation away from work. You're not quite sure how, if at all, to break the news to your partner.)
^After dinner, everyone plops down on the ancient couch. The TV hums in the background.

s: ^Peek at the TV for any news on the vote.

Gifts: ^There's a chorus of cheers as you distribute your goodies. The distraction proves thin though, and your dad soon turns on the television.
TVTime: ^The TV isn't showing the new vote, thankfully.
^Instead, it pans over a shot of the desert, tracking a small lizard.

g-0: ^The subtitled commentary gives you pause before pointing it out.
^"New geoengineering tactics in war allow for rapid civilian surrender as critical grain products dry up."
^As the lizard flicks out its tongue, the screen swaps to what looks like a vast horde of people walking across the desert. They look like they've been walking for far too long.
^"Civilian relief aids are concentrated in select cities, and many are escaping across vast plains to try reaching these citizens. Safe passage is not guaranteed."

s: ^Loudly redirect: "So, tell them what you've been doing at work?"

TurnTVoff: ^You cough and grab the remote, trying to calmly squish the off button.
^Your father raises an eyebrow at you.
^"Sorry, it was distracting." Your grin trembles.

b: ^ (And not the fact that you voted for geoengineering and weather manipulation).

TurnTVoff: ^"Your son's company has been mentioned in the news. Would you like to hear this now?" comes the cool, collected voice of the announcer.
DistractfromTV: ^Your partner launches into a tirade about the newest tax laws. Your lovely, wonderful partner, the activist accountant.
^You get distracted thinking about superhero names for political savior by night, pencil pusher by day.

b: ^It helps you forget that you voted for geoengineering. You didn't know it would cause famine though, it was a theoretical! An engineering experiment!
^ You didn't vote for geoengineering, but many did. But how could they have known their votes would be used to cause famine?

DistractfromTV: ^"Your son's company has been mentioned in the news. Would you like to hear this now?" comes the cool, collected voice of the announcer.
ArgumentTime: ^Your mother claps her hands in glee.
^"My friend showed me how to set news alerts! You know how you hate telling us anything about the work you're doing, and you take ages to show us anything?"

^Your father chimes in, "It's helped us find showcases of your firm's work from years ago. You never told us the firm worked on the vineyard less than 50 miles from here. Your mother and I drove out to look at it."
^While this could be something totally mundane, you just know it's going to be about that government contract at work.

s: ^"Maybe now's not the best time to look at work. It's the holidays."
^"Mom, dad, please let me have some boundaries."

g-0: ^Your partner decides that now's a good time for some light-hearted ribbing.
^"Oh, come on, show off a little."

s: ^Derail this into a conversation about how your parents are overreaching.
^Accept your fate. Hope the holiday spirit will soften the blow.

DerailConversation: ^You don't know whether or not you're including your partner in the 'guys'.
^"You won't just let me share what I want to share. You have to keep poking, and it makes me less willing to share."
^You're starting to babble, trying to keep things from being too hurtful while trying to just stop your mom from sharing whatever stupid breaking news is going to implode your relationship.
^Your partner lightly touches your hand, warning you to stop.

s: ^"Look, I'm sorry, but can we just drop work?"
^"Sorry, sorry, I got too worked up. Mom, if you want to share, please share."

DerailConversation2: ^"Wooh, big emotions today with everyone," your father comments banally.
^Your mother unconsciously digs her hands into the frays of the couch, worrying it.
^"I'm sorry dear, we didn't mean any harm by it."

s: ^Is it worth hurting them so much? You could confess.

AcceptFate: ^You could confess. Break your NDA. You didn't know what the contract would be used for. Honesty first, right?
^But, what if it's on something totally unrelated?

s: ^"There's something you should know about work."

WorkExplanation: ^You start to stand, but that feels too much like a speech.
^Sitting and staring at the ground feels too much like a confession.

b: ^ You wish the TV was still on, so you had something to look at.
^ The TV is still droning about the war, rubbing your face in it.

s: ^"We have a new contract at work."
^"I didn't know, okay? I still don't know."

NewContract: ^"They told us it was a new art project, on preserving modern day houses.
^But, I think- I mean, we've never taken out anything past 20th century preservation."
^Your father already knows what's coming. He talks less than your mother, but he listens a lot more.

s: ^Stumble and look to your father for help.

Stumble: ^Your father takes your mother's hands away from further fraying the couch fabric.
^"You don't have to tell us. I'm sure there's contracts you're breaking. Mary, leave it be."
^The white of your partner's eyes are scarily large. You imagine that you can see their blood vessels.
^Your mother's brows only convey confusion and hurt.
PushThrough: ^"The vote. I think that's my contract. They're using my work to do that."
Excuses: ^"John (your boss) just told us it was a modern art project. A way of preserving what will become history."
^You know you're dancing around the topic, and your pitch is reaching a screech.
^"What the hell are you talking about?" is the look on everyone's face.
ContinueExcuses: ^"I'm just an artist on the project. Well, the lead artist. And that's why I've had so much overtime."
^You can't seem to spit it out.
NewsBreak: ^"Well, we're certainly not going to look now."
